CatDescriptText: Miss Lulu Butler, custodian, 2922 Wylie Avenue and Mr. Tyson Pope, concessionaire, 731 Copeland Street, Shadyside, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 12, 1957, pg. 2 with question: "Do you think the Little Rock, Ark. school integration incident will gain more financial support for the NAACP in its continuing fight for equal rights?" Miss Lulu Butler's answer reads: "Sure, it will help. Everybody should support the NAACP because it has done more for the Negro race than any other organization."  Mr. Tyson Pope's answer reads: "If it hadn't been for the NAACP there never would have been a civil rights law.  The integration fight in Little Rock makes the NAACP entitled to more financial support."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of Lulu Butler wearing light colored dress, and Tyson Pope wearing eyeglasses and cap, standing in front of brick building with signs in window reading "Crush Proof Box Hit Parade," "Johnson['s]," and "Kaz Electric Vaporizer"
